labels.description: Change gas charging logic or weights

body:
```rust
fn gas_charge(gas_to_charge: u32) {}
```
This function compiles to
```wasm
i32.const $gas_to_charge ; <--- not charged now
call $gas_charge
```
There should be gas charge for this instruction too

title: Add test that processing allowance exceed works correctly
body:
### Problem to Solve

Check next attributes:
1. Message context is not saved in this case.
2. tbd..

### Possible Solution

1. Use demo-constructor to create a program, that in `handle` sends reply and unwraps result and then runs very expensive loop.
2. Call `run_to_block` with little `remaining_weight` so you reach the `GasAllowanceExceeded` error.
3. Run again `run_to_block` with larger `remaining_weight`.

We must receive successful execution result (sending reply must not panic the second time). 

### Notes

_No response_

title: refactor(core-backend): rename generics `core-backend` & `core-processor` so they emphasize their essence

labels.name: A0-pleasereview
labels.description: PR is ready to be reviewed by the team

body:
Resolves #2654 

This PR actually **renames** only several traits/types:
- `EnvironmentExecutionError` -> `EnvironmentError` (as environment actually doesn't execute, errors aren't much related to execution).
- `ProcessorError` -> `ExtError` (`ProcessorExt` trait can have `ProcessorExt` error, but there's no such associated type in this trait. What's more there's no additional helping context with "Processor*" prefix to the error, especially if we look at the type definition). Same for `ProcessorAllocError` -> `ExtAllocError`.

All other changes are **name extensions** (instead of short names or one-letter generic names, which made it hard to understand the code and definitions of some types):
- generic `EP` -> EntryPoint
- generic `A` in some functions of `core_processor::execute` -> `ProcessorExt`
- trait `Ext` -> `Externalities`
- trait `ProcessorExt` -> `ProcessorExternalities`
- generic `PrepMem` (and just `T` in some places) -> `PrepareMemoryError`
- generic `E` -> `Ext`. That was the most important as `E` is used in the same crate/package for `Environment`, some error and `Externalities` too.

Some rules used for changes:
- Traits are given full names
- Generics, associated types and common types can have either full or short name (like `Externalities` trait implementor is `Ext`).

title: feat(node): Add `gear-voucher` pallet

labels.name: A0-pleasereview
labels.description: PR is ready to be reviewed by the team

labels.name: B1-releasenotes
labels.description: The feature deserves to be added to the Release Notes

body:
Provides API for contract owners (actually, anyone can to it) to "sponsor" users by allocating some funds that can only be used to send messages to this particular program and which will cover both transaction fees and the gas cost (in case `value` is being sent, as well, it will have to be charged to the user's personal account).
This resembles a "payment voucher" mechanism in a usual retail store - hence the pallet name.

Sending messages in the described fashion is done via the dedicated `send_message_with_voucher` extrinsic added to the `gear` pallet.

From implementation perspective, the flow is very similar to the `anon` proxy (`pure` accounts) from the Substrate `proxy` pallet (and it's likely we could even get away using the out-of-the-box mechanism to get the same result) but in any case some wrapper around the `proxy` API would be useful to hide away the details and complexity of the latter which is a bit confusing. And the fee customisation might be also a bit trickier.

Here we don't introduce any additional storage maps thereby avoiding much overhead. A "voucher" is created for a user by calling the `pallet_gear_voucher::issue()` extrinsic that would create a keyless account in the `Balances` pallet unique for a `(account_id, program_id)` pair and transferring the voucher amount to it. Later, when users sends the `send_message_with_voucher` extrinsic, the fees are charged to this keyless account, and the gas tree created inside the extrinsic itself uses this account as the `external origin` so that the gas leftovers are refunded back to the voucher and not the message sender (the user) preventing potential abuse.
The `Balances` pallet takes care of removing this account if the voucher has been completely redeemed.
